p.s: Delaney is a man full of prejudice and anger against illegal immigrants, wichwhich is shown through the use of reported thought and speech as well as descriptions by the narrator.
Through the narratersnarrator's use of reported thought the readers get a close up, of the prejudice Delaney holds in him.

Before Delaney gets to see what is in the white cloth shoulder bag he builds up prejudices by beliving that the immigrant stole important personal belongings from the Cherrystone'sCherrystones: Delaney demanded, eyeing the satchel and imagining the Cherrystones' silverware in there, their VCR, Selda's jewleryjewelry (ll. 37ff).
This underlines that Delaney is an impulsive character, by handeling or prejudicing before he thinks.
This prejudice comes from traumatic experiencessexperiences wichwhich happen throughout the novel, for example when Delaney's car get'sgets stolen.
The use of reported speech brings also evidence to Delaney being a man, full of prejudice.

By referring to the fact, that the immigrant is in his private property and that he doesn't belong there: This is private property.You don't belong here (l. 39), the narrator even underlines mroe the prejudice side from Delaney.
Furthermore Delaney is not only filled with prejudice, but also hate and anger towards the Mexicans.

By using a scenic presentation and detailleddetailed description Todd Sweet called at his back, but he wasn't lsitening, his mind gone numb with ambivalence.He went up the block, barely registering the world spread out before him, glum, dogless, on his own (ll. 5ff), the narrator points out the anger to the readers.

This behaviour from Delaney clearly indicates his anger and hate towards the immigrants, by overseeing the chance that could have prevented the situation when Todd Sweet calls him, and just walking further while blending out the world around him.
This could also be describedescribed as him having an attentive and unfocused state of mind, while the whole anger takes him forward.

Moreover Delaney also expresses his anger by shouting at the Mexican: Don't give me that shit! (l. 50) and the use of ana parallelism: I'm calling the police.I know what you're doing up here, I know who you are, you're not fooling anybody (ll. 51f).
Throhugh this use of reported speech, the readers can see how Delaney wants to appear dominant in opposite to the Mexican.
On one side Delaney shouts at the man and threatens him by mentioning the police.
But on the other hand Delaney get'sgets also ready to fight the Mexican and to defend himself, if he has to: Delaney was riding, the crest of the moment, trembling, angry, ready for anything (l. 48).
Another important aspect is that Delaney also develops fear and panic thorughout the scene.
In the beginning Delaney starts to feel uncomfortable, after the Mexican answers his question: Delaney was not.He was uncomfortable.He was aggravated. (l. 31).
From this point on the panic grows more and more in Delaney.
For example, this is shown througthrough Delaney's reaction, by quickening his stride, when he first speaks up to the man.
Besides that Delaney makes a sashly aaicn, when the Mexican does not answer his question.

This action is narrated as a reported thought, wichwhich leads to, that the readers get to know that Delaney doesn't think, before he takes actions and that he only handelshandles this way, because he fears the Mexican and want'swants to appear more dominant, to mabye calm himself down: Delaney said, and before he could think, he had hold of the man's forearm, just above the wrist. After the man whipped his arm easily free, Delaney craves on one hand the help and support from someone else: Delaney looked around him for support, for a car, a child on a bike, Todd Sweet, anyone, but the street was deserted (ll. 52f).
This climax shows clearly to the reader, how helpless Delaney feels and how much of panic and fear he is in hold of.
But on the other hand Delaney starts to suspect unrealistic things, for example that the Mexican has a knife and developesdevelops a deathly fear.

The use of reported thought here, let'slets the readers feel what Delaney is feeling in this situation: He's got a knife, Delaney thought, a gun, and he went cold all over when the man reached into the satchel [...] (ll. 55ff).
In the end Delaney has a turning devalopmenddevelopment, when he finds out that the Mexican didn't lie.
He start'sstarts to requestion himself and his actions.
The use of a rethoricalrhetorical question: [...] what was he becoming (l. 61), leads to the readers getting a incist in the now confused and devastated Delaney.

In summary, through the use of a lot of different narrative techniques, the readers get a chance to have a close up on DelaneysDelaney's over all mixed feelings, referringrefering to anger, hate, fear, devastation and prejudices.
